title: Cinema orchestras and organs
brief_description: Melbourne’s Capitol Theatre became the home of the first large Wurlitzer Organ in the country, which was used to provide music and sound effects for silent films when the orchestra was not performing, while the Palais Pictures theatre had its own in-house orchestra.

constellations_primary.name: Sound and cinema
constellations_primary.description: Beginning with one of the first films to be screened at the Palais (a Melbourne cinema with its own outstanding resident orchestra) the constellation celebrates sound as an integral part of the connection between moving image work and audience.

description: Melbourne’s The Capitol Theatre is a historic landmark, visited not just by tourists but lovers of film. Designed by Walter Burley Griffin and Marion Mahoney Griffin, it opened on Swanston Street in 1924 and was the first large picture palace in Victoria. It also became the home of the first large Wurlitzer Organ in the country, which was used to provide music and sound effects for silent films when the orchestra was not performing. Across the city, St Kilda’s Palais Pictures opened in 1927 and had its own in-house orchestra. During World War II when there was a shortage of men, an all-female orchestra took over and performed at the Palais up until 1949.
